titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Richard Kostelanetz Collection
1961-1997
MSS 089
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Camilla Fojas, 1997. Finding aid updated by Laura Newsome, 2010. Accretions added by Lawrence Giffin, 2011.

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from Richard KostelanetzCollection Finding Aid.htm

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-06-25T14:14-0400

did.abstract: Richard Kostelanetz is a major figure in the New York City downtown literary and art scene, as well as a performer, critic, scholar and an authority on concrete poetry. Included in the collection are copies of his printed works, including essays, anthologies, assemblings, contributions to periodicals, etc. Included also are: videos, sound recordings, and other materials which Kostelanetz produced from 1961-1997.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The collection belonged to Boris Kostelanetz, Richard Kostelanetz' father, who donated the materials to the Fales Library in Jan. 1997. Full-length books were catalogued for the Downtown Collection and bear a bookplate acknowledging that they are the gift of Boris Kostelanetz. Periodical contributions, videos, audio recordings, and other materials were processed as a collection whose description follows. Accretions were added in 1998, 1999, and 2000.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers. Appointments are necessary for the use of manuscript and archival materials.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Collection use is subject to all copyright laws. Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the Director of Fales Library and Special Collections. Please contact fales.library@nyu.edu. or call 212 998 2596.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Richard Kostelanetz was born on May 14, 1940, in New York, NY. He is the son of Boris, a lawyer, and Ethel (Cory) Kostelanetz. He received his B.A. from Brown University in 1962 with honors. He pursued graduate study at King's College in London from 1964 to 1965 and received an M.A. from Columbia University in 1966.

Richard Kostelanetz is a writer, visual artist, critic, poet, composer, filmmaker, holographer, video artist, and lecturer. His administrative history includes a diversity of positions, including: British Broadcasting Corp., London, England, producer-interviewer of program "New Release," 1965- 66; Assembling Press, New York City, co-founder and president, beginning 1970; City University of New York, John Jay College of Criminal Justice, New York City, program associate in thematic studies. 1972-73; Future Press, New York City, literary director, 1976--; co-editor/publisher, Precisely: A Critical Magazine, 1977-84; RK Editions, New York City, sole proprietor, 1978--; coordinator-interviewer, "American Writing Today," Voice of America Forum Series, 1979-81; visiting professor of American studies and English at University of Texas at Austin in the Spring of 1977; guest of Mishkenot Sha'ananim, Jerusalem in 1979 and in 1986; guest of the DAAD Kunstlerprogramm in West Berlin, 1981-83; guest artist at WXXI-FM, Rochester, NY, 1975-76; Synapse, Syracuse University, 1975; Cabin Creek Center for Work and Environmental Studies, 1978; Electronic Music Studio of Stockholm, 1981, 1983, 1984, 1986, and 1988; Brooklyn College Center for Computer Music, 1982; WGBH-FM, Boston, 1983, Public Access Synthesizer Studio, New York City, 1983; Dennis Gabor Laboratory, Museum of Holography, 1985, 1989; Experimental TV Center, Owego, New York, 1985, 1986, 1987, 1989, and 1990; and Film/Video Arts, 1989.

Richard Kostelanetz has lectured and given readings of his poetry and fiction at numerous colleges and universities, including New York University, Cooper Union, Brown University, Harvard University, University of Iowa, Antioch College, Carnegie-Mellon University, University of Southern California, Rutgers University, Detroit Institute of Arts, and Barnard College. He has given one man exhibitions of visual art at numerous galleries. He has exhibited his holograms at the Museum of Holographyin New York City in 1978 and 1986. He has exhibited his book art, visual poetry, and other works in over 60 group exhibitions.

Kostelanetz has received the followings awards and fellowships: Woodrow Wilson fellow, 1962-63; Fulbright fellow, 1964-65; Pulitzer fellow in critical writing, 1965-66; Guggenheim fellow, 1967; Numbers: Poems and Stories was selected one of the Best Books of 1976 by the American Institute of Graphic Arts; National Endowment for the Arts grants in visual arts, 1976, 1978, 1979, and 1985, and in media arts, 1981, 1982, 1985, 1986, 1989, and 1990; Pushcart Prize, 1977; Ludwig Vogelstein Foundation grant, 1980; Coordinating Council of Literary Magazines editors' fellow, 1981; New York State Council on the Arts Media Services grant (through Future Press), 1982, and 1984; American Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers (ASCAP) Award in serious music composition, annually, 1983-1991; American Public Radio Program Fund grant, 1985; Ann Arbor Film Festival prize, 1986.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Richard Kostelanetz Collection is a comprehensive set of printed materials, videos, sound recordings, and other materials produced by Richard Kostelanetz, downtown writer, artist, performer, critic, scholar, and an authority on concrete poetry. The collection includes books, articles, artwork, recordings, videos, computer disks, and announcements of radio programs, readings and exhibitions by Richard Kostelanetz. It also includes a small number of articles about Kostelanetz. Included in the collection are copies of all printed works by Richard, including essays, anthologies, assemblings, contributions to periodicals, etc.
Series I: contains articles written by Richard Kostelanetz.
Series II: contains periodicals with contributions by Richard Kostelanetz.
Series III: contains reviews of Richard Kostelanetz's work.
Series IV: contains articles and books about Richard Kostelanetz.
Series VI: contains Richard Kostelanetz's radio program listings.
Series VII: contains audio recordings by Richard Kostelanetz.
Series VIII: contains announcements of readings by Richard Kostelanetz.
Series IX: This is a series containing miscellaneous material including a resume, press catalogues, computer disks, etc.
Series X: This series contains videotapes by Richard Kostelanetz.
Series XI: This series contains prints by Richard Kostelanetz.
Accretions 1998: This accretion contains material from series I, II, VI, VII, and VIII
Accretions 1999: This accretion contains material from series I, II, and IX.
Accretions 2000: This accretion contains material from series I, II, III, VII, VIII, and IX.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders are arranged alphabetically by subject/author heading.
The files are grouped into 10 subject-based series. There is no Series V, for reasons unknown.

Series XI: Prints

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Full-length books were catalogued for the Downtown Collection and bear a bookplate acknowledging that they are the gift of Boris Kostelanetz.
